It belongs to the family Araceae and is characterized by its distinctive, shield-shaped leaves that help it cling to tree trunks. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in an inflorescence called a spadix, surrounded by a spathe. Its roots are fibrous and adapted for epiphytic growth, allowing it to thrive in humid, shaded environments. Marcgravia cyrtonota is often found in rainforests, where it plays a role in the complex ecological interactions of the canopy.
